data.title: Compare And Contrast John Donne And The 17th Century - 1269 Words
data.text:
The seventeenth century was a time of universal expansion in Europe. Society was dealing with changes in monarchy, a civil war, a shift in religion, and advancements in science. These issues were reframing the role of individuals in society, their perspectives on faith, and the social structures of England. Writers of this period offered their own viewpoints as evidence of the issues and their influence on the common people. Specific examples of authors of this period who deal with seventeenth century issues and perspectives in their work are John Donne and John Milton. Common themes between these two authors are love, religion, and political views.

Initially Milton entered Christ’s College with the intention of becoming ordained in the Church of England. However, eventually he came to believe that he was destined to serve his language, his country, and his God as a poet. In a series of treatise he argued for church disestablishments and for the removal of bishops, for a republic government based on natural law and popular sovereignty, for the right of the people to dismiss from office and even execute their rulers, and the right to divorce on the grounds of incompatibility. Milton probably wrote some part of Paradise Lost in the late 1650’s and completed it after the Restoration, encompassing in it all he had thought, read, and experienced of tyranny, political controversy, evil, deception, love, and the need for companionship. This cosmic blank verse epic assimilates and critiques the epic tradition and Milton’s entire intellectual and literary heritage, classical and Christian.

Milton and Donne both created poetic works that dealt with the religious turmoil of the seventeenth century. Donne’s poems were addressed to a select few and not the public at large. His poems were more about his inward emotions and how he felt as an individual in that society, not about society. In contrast Milton’s poems were meant for the public. He developed several tracts with radical arguments against the ruling party and the public. He was among the first to publicly attack the power of bishops.
